Posts.Content: On Jul 19, 2016 4:11 AM OhGee wrote: Hi, I had a screening mammogram recently that indicated "asymmetrical focal density" in my right breast. I had a diagnostic mammogram and last week had an ultrasound. Today I was advised that I am being scheduled for a core biopsy. Should I assume that the previous tests are suspicious for malignancy & the biopsy will confirm it? Has anyone else experienced this? Thank you I found lump and was sent to the breast clinic in my local hospital.# I was due for an annual mammogram but the lump appeared first. I went had a core biopsy and was more or less told that the lump was suspicious. The out come was that I have breast cancer in mt left breast and have had a lumpectomy an four nodes talken. Things have moved at pace and I've having chemo, then radiotherapy. This is all very frightening I know for you. I pray all works out well for you x
Posts.Title: Mammograms (2); Ultra Sound ~ Waiting for a Biopsy

Posts.Content: Hello, my name is Lesley. I'am 68. I found a lump in my left breast 2 weeks ago and went to the breast clinic to have it checked out. After tests mammogram and a core biopsy, I was told I had cancer, the biopsy would give the Drs an answer to what sort of cancer its was, I will be back to find out Monday 16th. I know there will be an Op and there will be a discussion on treatment. The worry is my husband has terminal Pancreatic Cancer, I'm his main carer and all this is happening when my husband has started to deteriate. He may have to go in the Hospice for respite, I promised him I would look after him at home it looks as if I may have to break my promise x
Posts.Title: Newly Diagnosed with Breast Cancer.

Posts.Content: On May 17, 2016 6:22 PM KettleKween wrote: Are you having masectomy or lumpectomy. What size is the tumor? I had a bit of a meltdown last night, the whole cancer thing got to me. I was very upset about losing Tommy and all the news I had to take on board with my diagnosis, I told my daughter that I was going to ring Jenny my Macmillan nurse, then just out the blue she rang me as like magic. I told her I had been overwhelmed and was afraid of the pain, she said "you would not be in pain", that would be seen to. I told her about me having a partial mastectomy and reconstruction, she said you are having a Wide Local Excision of the Breast, not a partial mastectomy, she explained that I would have my breast lifted but not reconstructed, the symmetry and position of my breasts would happen in 12months until then I would have one perky breast, her words. I feel much better and not so worried anymore, Things were lost in translation. My Dr is Indian.
Posts.Title: Newly Diagnosed with Breast Cancer.

Posts.Content: I have had the result of my biopsy and breast cancer has been confirmed on 9th May, I will have my surgery on 14th June. I will have have breast reconstruction done at the same time. The surgeon will remove one or two nodes to check if they are cancer free. Three weeks of radiotherapy and tabs for five years.
Posts.Title: Newly Diagnosed with Breast Cancer.

Posts.Content: On May 12, 2016 5:51 PM Possibilities wrote: Hello Lesley! I am so sorry about your diagnosis and I know how scary and overwhelming it all feels right now.  I am 61 and going through my second round of cancer after first being diagnosed with breast cancer in 2010. First, stop, close your eyes, take a deep breath and then slowly let it out.  Imagine yourself breathing in Peace and exhaling Anxiety.  There is no need to rush into any immedicate choices or decisions. When you meet with your doctors again, they will make recommendations and you will have choices.  Remember!  You have time to go home and think about everything and do your research first to decide what is best for you.  They will suggest a lumpectomy or mastectomy based on your cancer.  The follow up treatment may consist of radiation, chemotherapy, medication or a combination.  The choice will be yours after their suggestions.  Depending on your current health and physical ability, you may be able to keep caring for your husband at home.  If you are in good physical shape other than the cancer, and depending on your treatment choices, you may come through all this fairly easily.  I was able to keep working with just a week off after surgery.  I felt more tired during treatment and slept more, but kept on doing what I had always done.  Even went hiking a few times! I am very sorry to hear about your husband's condition as well.  Remember though that you need to think about your own needs just as much now.  Hospice offers in-home care in most cases so your husband may not need to leave.  Having someone available to give you a few hours to yourself each day would be wonderful.  Do not be afraid to let others know you could use some help!  Many of us have a hard time asking for ourselves but this is one of those times when you need to accept all the help available to you.  Most cancer centers, that I'm aware of, have people to help you find what you need with these kinds of situations.  Joining a support group, if you haven't already, might also help with some of the stress and being overwhelmed. I wish you both the very best.  Do not dwell on the sadness of all this.  Enjoy and laugh every minute you can; watch funny movies; read inspirational stories; reflect on the good times; get out in the sun and live life.  Sometimes we have to fake it till me make it. Best wishes,  Janet                                                                   Thank you for your reply and enccouragement. I will know more on  Monday. so may be in touch again x

Posts.Content: On May 13, 2016 2:23 AM ladyfromdgo wrote: Hi Lesley. I'm 65, and my name is Laurie.  First of all, you seem to have your ducks in a row, however, wait until you get the result before you even think of panicking.  I found a lump at Christmastime, and had the needle biopsy, which showed "mucinous adenocarcinoma".  I was given the option of lumpectomy, after which I would have to at least have 6 weeks of radiation, or mastectomy, either one or both breasts.  I chose bilateral mastectomy, with reconstruction and implants at the same time.  The doctors didn't push one way or the other.  It was my choice.  My sentinel node biopsies (they check the lymph nodes while doing the other surgery, and they can find out right away whether they're a problem or not) were all negative.  They also sent a portion of my tumor to a reference lab that did what they call "oncotype", and that gives a numerical rating as to what your risk my be for recurring cancer.  Mine was low, which was great.  To shorten this a bit, what I'm getting at is the fact that the results may not be as terrible as what we automatically think.  I did not have to have radiation or chemo.  I feel great, and with my low risk of recurrence, I chose not to do the hormone treatment that they recommend when your pathology comes back showing estrogen receptor positive.  I read so many messages regarding women feeling fairly terrible while taking these, so that again was my choice.  Because I feel good right now, I don't want to take something that has fairly often caused women to feel bad.  Like you, dealing with your husband who sounds like his cancer is terminal, I lost my husband last July from Glioblastoma Grade 4, a very aggressive, fast growing brain cancer.  He had surgery, then radiation and chemo, and was with me exactly one year from the day of diagnosis.  This may slant my feelings about treatment, but because his brain cancer kept growing, I can't attribute any pain or illness he had to the treatment.  I just know that life is fleeting, and quality is important to what we have of it.  Don't worry.  You will deal with this the best way for you, but wait until you have all the facts before making decisions.  Love yourself and your husband, to death.  Then choose what route you take.  Please keep us posted as to what is happening.  Take care of you.  Laurie I wish yoy well, I would thank you for your positive feedback. I feel I have to smile and be happy in front of my family as my girls are so upset because over their beloved Dad, he is undergoing palliative care. I need to be strong x
